Issues.Title: TabControl.TabPageCollection.RemoveAt(int) removes wrong item!
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

All .NET versions to .NET 6

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Same bug in all previous .NET versions & .NET Framework

### Issue description

This RemoveAt method in System.Windows.Forms.TabControl.TabPageCollection has a horrible bug that can cause it to remove the wrong page from the TabControl.

There's only one line of code in the method, so the bug is obvious:

`owner.Controls.RemoveAt(index);`

You can see that it's applying the index to the **Controls** collection rather than the **TabPages** collection. These two collections are not the same; they can sometimes get out of sync when the SelectedTab changes. You used to be able to work around the bug by setting the [AllowUpdateChildControlIndexForTabControls application switch](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/compatibility/winforms#allowupdatechildcontrolindexfortabcontrols-compatibility-switch-not-supported) to false, but this switch is no longer supported.

You can fix the bug by changing that line of code to:

`owner.Controls.Remove(this[index]);`

### Steps to reproduce

I don't think this is needed - the bug is obvious from looking at the one line of code.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TabControl.TabPageCollection.RemoveAt(int) removes wrong item!" (#7837)

Issues.Title: [release/7.0] Set IsPassword property for TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject
Issues.Body:
Fixes #7816.
.NET 8.0 PR: #7825
IsPassword property determines whether keystrokes should be read out by screen reader as the user types them.

This is a regression from https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6640, which sets `IsPassword` as false for every control. Before it, `IsPassword` was `null` for `TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject` and therefore its value was taken from MSAA provider.

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

## Servicing reasons

- This regression makes screen readers announce content entered into TextBoxes configured for password input, which may expose sensitive information for screen reader users.

## Proposed changes

- Use `TextBoxBase.PasswordProtect` to determine `IsPassword` property value

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- When `TextBox` is configured as password input, screen readers will not announce keystrokes as the user types them, because it may expose private information.

## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Minimal - we are putting the old code back

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

`IsPassword` value is `False` for `TextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`:

![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is false for TextBox containing a password](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191802455-0f83549e-5a79-481f-a8b9-65464e4a3323.png)

Narrator Buddy output as "qwerty" is entered into the `TextBox`:

> edit, 
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">q</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">w</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">e</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">r</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">t</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">y</say-as>

Same result for:

- `TextBox` with non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `MaskedTextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true` or non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and non-empty `PasswordChar`

### After

`IsPassword` value is `True` for `TextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`:
![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is true for TextBox containing a password](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191799987-ef76a1c6-f616-4e79-9046-dab4640c97bb.png)

Narrator Buddy output as "qwerty" is entered into the `TextBox`:

> edit, 
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden

Same result for:

- `TextBox` with non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `MaskedTextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true` or non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and non-empty `PasswordChar`

For `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`, `IsPassword` property remains `False`, because with this combination it's not formatted as password:
![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is false for Multiline TextBox with UseSystemPasswordChar = true](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191801510-f26ce1f7-611c-4388-bde4-dbb1bc851bb7.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Unit tests
- CTI

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

- Using Narrator and AI
<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->
 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- 7.0.100-rc.1.22431.12
- Windows 11

<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] AutomationID property should not be empty for dropdown items under ImageAlign/TextAlign/CheckAlign/Dock in PropertyGrid
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 8.0 SDK: 8.0.100-alpha.1.22469.15

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

In .Net 3.1, this issue cannot repro, and .Net 6.0 and 7.0 can repro

### Issue description

AutomationID property should not be empty for dropdown items under ImageAlign/TextAlign/CheckAlign/Anchor/Dock property in PropertyGrid

Inspect:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/191923568-dd6a96bd-2c97-4007-8bf2-b9070d9687ee.png)



### Steps to reproduce

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a winforms core app with PropertyGrid and RadioButton control.
2. Associate the Button with PropertyGrid as a selected object.
3. Build and run the core project.
4. Start Inspect tool.
5. Open the drop down list next to ImageAlign.
6. Focus on "Top Center" and observe AutomationID property in Inspect.

Tested app: 
[WinFormsApp13.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/9632177/WinFormsApp13.zip)

Issues.Title: TextBox should set IsPassword accessible property when it contains password
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0.100-alpha.1.22423.9

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Worked in .NET 6 but not in .NET 7, didn't check earlier versions

### Issue description

From [Edit docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-supporteditcontroltype#relevant-properties) on [UIA_IsPasswordPropertyId](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-automation-element-propids) property:

> Must be set to TRUE on edit controls that contain passwords. If an edit control does contain Password contents then this property can be used by a screen reader to determine whether keystrokes should be read out as the user types them.

There are `UseSystemPasswordChar` and `PasswordChar` properties on `TextBox` that allow formatting content as password.

### Current behavior:

When setting either `UseSystemPasswordChar` or `PasswordChar` properties on a `TextBox`, the `IsPassword` property stays `False`. 

![A screenshot of a form with 2 text boxes formatted as passwords. Accessibility Insights app shows that IsPassword property is false](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191551252-40912925-fcf4-45a7-b9d2-64699ad0134e.png)

Narrator announces all symbols entered into such text boxes.

### Expected behavior:

When setting either `UseSystemPasswordChar` or `PasswordChar` properties on a `TextBox`, the `IsPassword` property becomes `True`, and screen readers don't announce characters entered into it. 

### Steps to reproduce

Sample application:
[TextBoxPasswordSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/9627198/TextBoxPasswordSample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "TextBox should set IsPassword accessible property when it contains password" (#7816)

Issues.Title: Set IsPassword property for TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject
Issues.Body:
Fixes #7816.
IsPassword property determines whether keystrokes should be read out by screen reader as the user types them.

This is a regression from https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6640, which sets `IsPassword` as false for every control. Before it, `IsPassword` was `null` for `TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject` and therefore its value was taken from MSAA provider.

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->


## Proposed changes

- Use `TextBoxBase.PasswordProtect` to determine `IsPassword` property value

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- When `TextBox` is configured as password input, screen readers will not announce keystrokes as the user types them, because it may expose private information.

## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

`IsPassword` value is `False` for `TextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`:

![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is false for TextBox containing a password](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191802455-0f83549e-5a79-481f-a8b9-65464e4a3323.png)

Narrator Buddy output as "qwerty" is entered into the `TextBox`:

> edit, 
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">q</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">w</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">e</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">r</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">t</say-as>
> <say-as interpret-as="spell">y</say-as>

Same result for:

- `TextBox` with non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `MaskedTextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true` or non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and non-empty `PasswordChar`

### After

`IsPassword` value is `True` for `TextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`:
![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is true for TextBox containing a password](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191799987-ef76a1c6-f616-4e79-9046-dab4640c97bb.png)

Narrator Buddy output as "qwerty" is entered into the `TextBox`:

> edit, 
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden
> Hidden

Same result for:

- `TextBox` with non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `MaskedTextBox` with `UseSystemPasswordChar = true` or non-empty `PasswordChar`
- `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and non-empty `PasswordChar`

For `TextBox` with `Multiline = true` and `UseSystemPasswordChar = true`, `IsPassword` property remains `False`, because with this combination it's not formatted as password:
![A screenshot with Application Insights showing that IsPassword is false for Multiline TextBox with UseSystemPasswordChar = true](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191801510-f26ce1f7-611c-4388-bde4-dbb1bc851bb7.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Unit tests
- CTI

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

- Using Narrator and AI

     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

Issues.Title: TextBox should set HelpText accessible property when it contains placeholder text
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0.100-alpha.1.22423.9

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

From [Edit docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-supporteditcontroltype):

> If an edit control contains placeholder text (for example, a cue banner), the text should be used as the HelpText property unless the text can be edited by the user and then reused as placeholder text. For example, the Windows Internet Explorer address bar contains the text "about:Tabs" when a new tab is opened. This is not HelpText because it is a programmatic address that can be used or edited by the user.

There is a `PlaceholderText` property on a `TextBox` which acts as a placeholder. It cannot be edited by the user and disappears when `TextBox` gets focus, thus needs to be exposed as a `HelpText`.

### Current behavior:

When setting `PlaceholderText` property on a `TextBox` with empty text, the `HelpText` property stays empty, and placeholder isn't announced by screen readers. 

![A screenshot of a form with 3 text boxes, where the second TextBox has a placeholder text. Accessibility Insights app shows that HelpText property is empty on a second text box](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/191537863-d5c3ef16-8a38-48b6-a132-9b205f88c806.png)

Narrator Buddy output when switching between these TextBoxes:

> edit, Text box 1, 
> edit, 
> edit, Text box 3, 

Placeholder text is not announced.

### Expected behavior:
When `PlaceholderText` is non-empty and `Text` is empty, `HelpText` accessible property should have value of `PlaceholderText`. As a result, it should also be announced by screen readers. 

### Steps to reproduce

Sample application:
[TextBoxPlaceholderSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/9617884/TextBoxPlaceholderSample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TextBox should set HelpText accessible property when it contains placeholder text" (#7815)

Issues.Title: [release/7.0] Fixing the border's color of TextBox inside MenuStrip
Issues.Body:
Backport of #7759 to release/7.0

/cc @Tanya-Solyanik @NikitaSemenovAkvelon

# MenuStripTextBoxes don't have visible borders in HightContrast themes

## Description
Before
![No Border around TextBox In HighContrast](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/191387049-f348e20a-837c-4b1b-8f8d-ca9eb207168c.png)

After - 
Draw a border in HighContrast themes using the standard color for menu borders.

![Same Border Around TextBox As We Have Around ComboBoxes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/191387112-28192f1b-6a2c-45a3-b4da-e4c7b325ef6d.png)

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/7740

## Customer Impact
Customer does not know that this is an input field when using High Contrast mode.

## Regression?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

## Risk

- [ ] High
- [ ] Medium
- [x] Low - restricted to HighContrast mode and the same color is used in Buttons

## Verification

- [x] Manual (required) - Win10.Win11, on HighContrast and regular themes
- [ ] Automated

## Packaging changes reviewed?

- [ ] Yes
- [ ] No
- [x] N/A

----
